slides.title: The Distribution Mix: Getting Products to Customers
content: Distribution mix combines channels to get products to users efficiently and strategically.
Intermediaries, like wholesalers and retailers, assist in moving products through the distribution channels.
Channel members are the organizations participating in facilitating the movement of goods.
Distribution channels are the paths products follow from manufacturers to end users, requiring strategy.
slides.script: Welcome to Chapter 13. This slide introduces the concept of the distribution mix and explains how it's a combination of different channels to get products to consumers. It also highlights the role of intermediaries and channels in the distribution process.

slides.title: Distribution Strategies: Finding the Right Fit
content: Distribution strategies vary from intensive (many channels) to exclusive (limited channels).
Intensive distribution aims for maximum market coverage, like candy available everywhere.
Exclusive distribution grants rights to a few, often used for premium goods like Rolex watches.
Selective distribution provides special attention from chosen wholesalers and retailers.
slides.script: This slide explains different distribution strategies. Intensive distribution is about getting your product everywhere, while exclusive is for luxury items and selective is somewhere in between, choosing specific partners. It's all about finding the right strategy for your product.

slides.title: Channel Conflict and Leadership
content: Channel conflict arises when channel members disagree over roles or rewards, causing inefficiencies.
Channel leadership involves a dominant member, the channel captain, determining roles and rewards.
Coordination and collaboration between the distribution channel is critical for continued success.
Efficient distribution requires each member’s participation, even though conflict may develop.
slides.script: This slide explains that conflict can arise in distribution channels, and it also introduces the channel captain – the dominant member, which helps coordinate activities among members to resolve conflicts.

slides.title: Wholesaling: Serving Businesses
content: Wholesaling involves intermediaries selling products to other businesses, not final consumers.
Merchant wholesalers buy products and sell them to other businesses.
Agents and brokers act as sales representatives for producers, earning commissions.
Merchant Wholesalers and Agents are critical for reaching businesses.
slides.script: Now we move into wholesaling. Merchant Wholesalers are independent operations that sell various goods produced by various manufacturers. They own the goods that they resell and provide storage and delivery. Agents and brokers serve as independent sales representatives and sell goods on a commission basis but do not own the goods.

slides.title: E-Intermediaries: Online Wholesaling
content: E-intermediaries are online channel members facilitating information and online product delivery.
Syndicated selling provides commissions to websites referring customers.
Shopping agents gather and sort information to help online consumers find best deals.
E-intermediaries transform distribution through the information and support they provide.
slides.script: E-intermediaries have changed the dynamics of distribution significantly. These are online channel members who facilitate information, referrals, and deliveries online. Syndicated Selling provides commissions to websites that refer customers. Shopping Agents help online consumers by gathering and sorting product information.

slides.title: Retailing: Connecting with Consumers
content: Retailing involves selling products directly to consumers through various outlets.
Brick-and-mortar retailers include product-line retailers, bargain retailers, and convenience stores.
Product-line retailers: Large stores organized by departments offering wide selections and services.
Bargain retailers offer wide product ranges at lower prices and convenience.
slides.script: This slide examines Retailing. Product-line retailers, bargain retailers, and convenience stores all work to attract different customer segments. Product-line retailers are large stores, with a wide range of selection and services. Bargain retailers try to offer a wide range of products at lower prices and Convenience Stores try to provide accessibility and speedy service.

slides.title: Retailing: Nonstore Options
content: Nonstore retailing includes vending machines and direct-response methods.
Vending machines offer convenient, automated sales of limited goods and services.
Direct-response retailing engages customers directly to inform and solicit sales orders.
Catalog marketing, telemarketing, and direct selling are all forms of direct response.
slides.script: Nonstore Retailing means selling products without a physical brick-and-mortar presence. That includes selling via Vending machines. Direct Response Retailing involves directly contacting customers. That can take on many different forms such as online and telephone interaction.

slides.title: Online Retailing: The E-Commerce Boom
content: Online retailing allows sellers to inform, sell, and distribute using online technology.
E-catalogs offer online product displays, cutting printing and distribution costs.
Electronic storefronts are websites where shoppers gather product information and make purchases.
Cybermalls connect shoppers to diverse virtual storefronts offering varied products.
slides.script: Online Retailing has grown immensely. E-Catalogs, electronic storefronts and cybermalls allow customers a variety of options.

slides.title: Physical Distribution: Moving the Goods
content: Physical distribution is the movement of products from intermediaries or manufacturers to customers.
Warehousing stores inventory, which can be private or public.
Transportation moves products, influencing speed and cost using modes like trucks, rail, or air.
Effective distribution provides products when and where customers want them.
slides.script: Physical distribution entails activities needed to move products from manufacturers, and intermediaries to customers and includes warehousing and transportation. The aim is to make products available on time, while managing costs.

slides.title: The Importance of Promotion: Communicating Value
content: Promotion involves techniques to communicate product information effectively.
Promotional objectives: increasing sales, communicating information, positioning products, adding value.
The communication mix is key to developing a promotional approach.
The communication mix must effectively target specific audiences.
slides.script: Here's an introduction to promotion. The importance of promotion involves communicating valuable information and is a key component of the overall communication mix. Marketers need to communicate the benefits of their products effectively to their target audiences.

slides.title: Promotional Strategies: Push vs. Pull
content: A pull strategy appeals directly to consumers, creating demand from retailers.
A push strategy markets products to wholesalers and retailers, who then persuade customers.
Many firms combine both push and pull strategies.
Selecting the best method requires awareness of potential customers.
slides.script: Two different promotional strategies include the pull, which appeals directly to consumers who in turn will demand from retailers, and the push, which pushes goods to wholesalers and retailers so that they push out to customers.

slides.title: Promotional Mix: Combining Communication Tools
content: Promotional mix uses a combination of advertising, personal selling, sales promotions, and more.
Advertising is paid nonpersonal communication, informing audiences about products.
Personal selling communicates one-on-one with customers, aligning needs with products.
Promotional mix must effectively target a specific audience.
slides.script: Now we move on to promotional mix – advertising and personal selling. Advertising is a paid form of nonpersonal communication used by an identified sponsor. Personal selling involves a salesperson communicating with potential customers to identify their needs and address those needs with products.

slides.title: Sales Promotions: Incentives for Buying
content: Sales promotions offer short-term incentives to encourage buying, increasing sales revenues.
Free samples let customers try products risk-free.
Coupon promotions offer discounts to encourage customers to buy products.
Loyalty programs reward frequent buyers for repeat purchases, increasing sales.
slides.script: Sales promotions are a very important component of the promotional mix and help to encourage buying, increase recognition, and increase revenue. Free samples, coupons, loyalty programs, and other options may incentivize the consumer.

slides.title: Direct and Public Relations: Connecting and Informing
content: Direct marketing aims for one-on-one, nonpersonal selling, often used online.
Publicity is free media information about a company, influencing public attention.
Public relations builds goodwill and manages unfavorable events.
Promotional campaigns need to be clear, concise, and targeted.
slides.script: Finally, direct marketing and public relations also comprise the promotional mix. Direct Marketing entails one-on-one nonpersonal selling via mail and Internet and other connections with customers and publicity is free information broadcast by media.
